entry.title: Re: Safer sighashes and more granular SIGHASH_NOINPUT
entry.summary:
In a discussion about the trade-offs between protocol complexity and software reliability within the Bitcoin ecosystem, Rusty Russell highlights an important distinction. The focus is on balancing the intricacies of the core protocol against the complexities that can arise within wallet software. Russell argues that while both areas are crucial, the consequences of failures in each differ significantly in scale and impact. A failure in the core protocol of Bitcoin could have severe repercussions for every user of the currency, suggesting that prioritizing simplicity in the core protocol is essential. On the other hand, issues within wallet software, though potentially serious, typically affect a far smaller group of users. This perspective suggests a strategic approach to development priorities within the Bitcoin community, advocating for a simpler core protocol to ensure broader security and stability, while recognizing that wallet software problems, though undesirable, are somewhat more contained in their effects.
For further reading and insights, Russell points to resources available at [Peter Todd's website](https://petertodd.org), which offers a deeper dive into the nuances of cryptocurrency protocols and their implications for users and developers alike. This reference serves as an invitation to explore more specialized discussions and analyses related to Bitcoin's technical challenges and design considerations.
